texts.en: Mujidat is 35 years old and married with three children. She sells smoked and fried fish.  She is requesting a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more fish. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita V. is from the village of Purok 2, Resthouse, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 45 years old. Carmelita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Carmelita owns & operates a business raising cops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Carmelita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional corn seeds & young crops to raise. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used for the education of her three kids. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Carmelita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and to support her family's basic needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For the education of her three kids

location.town: Purok 2, Resthouse, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio S. manages a small parcel of land. He is 53 years old already and has four children. He is a tenant of the land he is tilling. He gets a share from the harvest. He uses his harvest to feed his family and buy their other needs.

He wants to avail a loan of PHP 8,000. He will use the loan to buy farm inputs like fertilizer, insecticide and seeds. He believes that his loan will give him better produce compared to his last harvest.

CEVI helps small business grow. CEVI provides not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Adeola

texts.en: Adeola is 37 years old and married with three children. She sells provisions and drinks to make a living. She is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Oeur

texts.en:
Oeur M. is a 46-year-old village woman who has had a job as a rice farmer since she was single. In addition, she currently sells fresh fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing or that she buys from her wholesale supplier and other fisherman. She runs her business in the market and is earning approximately of $2 a day. Her husband is a local fisherman. The humble couple has three children who are no longer in school and are working with their businesses.

This approaching fishing season, the lakes are full of fish but the family is lacking tools to fish with. Therefore, Oeur M. is applying for a loan for her husband to purchase additional fishing equipment in order to support his business activities.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing equipment

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en:
Taiwo is 40 years old and married with three children. She has a shop where she sells gift items and wedding accessories.

She is requesting the loan of N100,000 to purchase more gift items and wedding accessories to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more gift items and wedding accessories to sell

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: Merlinda I. is a pig grower. She is 55 years old and has twelve children. She started her business with only one pig but, through the help of her husband and CEVI, she managed to grow and sustain her business all the more. The income she gets from her piggery is what she uses to pay the tuition of her children in college. She also wants to expand her pig business in the future. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase pig feed. She believes that her loan will give her a better chance to improve her livelihood. CEVI helps small businesses to grow. It provides not only loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en:
C. is 25 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than six years. She sells fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing or buys them from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen.

She is married to Run Sok, 29, who works at fishing in and around the lakes of his community. Currently, the fishing is temporarily interrupted because the fishing equipment is broken. Because of this reason, that is why C. requested a loan in order to buy additional fishing equipment.

loans.use: To buy additional fishing equipment for her husband

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est constitué  de femmes mariées  ayant en moyenne 28 ans, 2 enfants et  vivant dans  des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de boubous bazin, de poissons fumés, de la friperie et également des prestations de services (teinture)
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts précédents se sont  bien dénoués.
 Elles comptent acheter avec ce nouveau prêt ,15 complets bazin (moins riche non teintés) de motifs différents, 4 paniers de poissons fumés, 3 balles de friperie,  7 paquets de colorants,  50 kg de soude caustique et 1 chargement de fagot. Elles s’approvisionnent  à Bamako (capitale du Mali), au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans  les localités avoisinantes. Les marchandises sont vendues  la plupart au comptant, dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.750 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée comme épargne et l’autre partie investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi ambitionnent augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi is composed of married women have an average age of 28 and two children. They live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They operate diverse businesses, including the selling of damask boubous (long flowing outfits), smoked, fish, and second-hand clothing, and also a range of services (the dyeing of cloth). The group members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy customer needs and are now on their fifth solidarity loan. All the preceding loans have been settled. With this new loan, they intend to buy 15 damask outfits (less-rich and un-dyed) of different patterns, 4 baskets of smoked fish, 3 bales of used clothing, 7 packets of colorings, 50 kg of caustic soda, and 1 load of firewood bundles. Supplies are procured in Bamako (capital of Mali) at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City and in neighboring towns. The merchandise is sold for the most part in cash transactions at the different markets of Sikasso and in the districts. Their customers are composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing a monthly profit of 15,750 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be put into savings, and the other portion will be invested in business. Their ambition is to increase their turnover, so as to satisfy their customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: "I started my piggery with only one sow. For a long time, I have been able to manage my business well... of course with the help of my husband and CEVI. The income I get from my pigs is what I use to pay all the expenses in our home," says Jocelyn L., 48-year old mother of eight children. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase pig feed. The loan will truly help her grow and sustain her business. CEVI is reaching out to a lot of pig raisers. It provides not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed

loans.name: Danaya. Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya de l’association Benkadi AMIDEF sont tous des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et ayant en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur septième  prêt solidaire. Tous les précédents prêts ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments, d’huile alimentaire, d’atiéké, des fritures,  des brochettes et des plats alimentaires. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 5 sacs de 100 kg de pomme de terre, 9 bidons de 20 litres d’huile alimentaire, 3 sacs d’atieké, 1 paquet d’ingrédients, 1 sac de riz, 3 paquets de condiments alimentaire et 1chargement de charrette en bois de chauffe. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et  dans les localités avoisinantes. Les marchandises sont vendues dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant. 
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  comme épargne et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Danaya ambitionnent augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The members of the group Danaya of the association Benkadi AMIDEF are all married women who average 36 years of age and 2 children each. They live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy customer needs and are now on their seventh solidarity loan. All the preceding loans have been repaid. The group members operate diverse businesses, including the selling of condiments, atiéké (dried fermented cassava), fried foods, kebabs, and culinary dishes. With this new loan, they intend to buy five 100-kg sacks of potatoes, nine 20-liter drums of cooking oil, three sacks of atiéké, a packet of ingredients, a sack of rice, three packets of condiments, and a cart-load of firewood. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City and in neighboring towns. The merchandise is sold for the most part in cash transactions at the different markets of Sikasso and in the districts. Their customers are composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 17,500 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be put into savings, and the other portion will be invested in business. Their ambition is to increase their turnover, so as to satisfy their customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
The three people shown in the picture are Mrs. S., her husband, and their child, who reside in Phnom Penh City of Cambodia.

S. is a local farmer, growing a variety kind of green vegetables on her own farmland that was inherited from her grandmother. Her husband is a fisherman who depends on fishing around the ponds of their community, which is enough for both selling and eating. The couple has given birth to one son who is now a lovely baby and under their care.

S. will use the Kiva loan to purchase a boat and more equipment for her husband to use in fishing.

loans.use: To purchase a boat and more fishing equipment for her husband to use

loans.name: Danaya. Group

texts.fr:
Danaya de l’association Sindiya AMIDEF est un regroupement de femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali.) 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursé le prêt précédent. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente du  bois de chauffe, du savon traditionnel, des condiments alimentaires et divers  autres petits articles.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 300 morceaux de savons traditionnels (farakourouni), 4 paquets de condiments et d’autres petits articles. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les localités avoisinantes. Les marchandises sont vendues la plupart au comptant, dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 11.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour rembourser le prêt et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Danaya ambitionnent augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire leur clientèle.
texts.en:
Danaya, of the association Sindiya AMIDEF, is a group of married women who have an average of age of 36 and four children. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy customer needs and are now on their second solidarity loan. All the preceding loans have been repaid. The women run diverse businesses, including the sale of firewood, traditional soap, condiments, and various and sundry goods. With this new loan, they intend to buy a truck-load of firewood, 300 bars of traditional soap (farakourouni), 4 packets of condiments, and other items. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City and in neighboring towns. The merchandise is sold mostly in cash transactions at the different markets of Sikasso and in the districts. Their customers are composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 11,500 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be put into savings, and the other portion will be invested in business. Their ambition is to increase their turnover, so as to satisfy their customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Mojeed

texts.en: Mojeed is 43 years old and married with three children. He sells VCDs (Video CDs) and building materials. He also has a phone booth. He is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more building materials and VCDs to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials and VCDs to sell

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kotognogontala sont toutes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans  et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur huitième  prêt solidaire, après avoir remboursés les prêts précédents sans aucune difficulté.
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de produits alimentaires, ménagers et des prestations de service.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 150 morceaux de savons traditionnels (farakourouni), 2 balles de tissus (pour hommes et femmes), 1 douzaine de laine de couleurs différentes, 5 aiguilles et crochets, des colorants  et de la soude caustique. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les localités avoisinantes. Les marchandises sont vendues dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant. 
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour la santé et la nourriture des enfants  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Kotognogontala ambitionnent augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The women of the group Kotognogontala are all married and have an average age of 32 and three children. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy customer needs and are now on their eighth solidarity loan. All the preceding loans have been repaid. The women operate diverse businesses, including the sale of food items and household products, and they offer a range of services. With this new loan, they intend to buy a truck-load of firewood, 150 bars of traditional soap (farakourouni), 2 bales of fabrics (for men and women), a dozen units of wool of different colors, 5 crochet needles, some dyes, and some caustic soda. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City and in neighboring towns. The merchandise is sold mostly in cash transactions at the different markets of Sikasso and in the districts. Their customers are composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 10,500 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used for the health and nourishment of the children, and the other portion will be invested in business. Their ambition is to increase their turnover, so as to satisfy their customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Kodjo Séanyo

texts.fr: Ce monsieur habite le quartier d’adidogomé, un quartier de la ville de Lomé, il est marié à une femme qui est ménagère. Afin de subvenir aux charges de la famille, il a commencé le commerce de charbons de bois. Il fait ce commerce depuis 2006 et s’approvisionne à tsévié une ville à l’intérieur du pays. Il est le seul à faire cette activité dans son quartier, ce qui fait qu’il réalise de bonnes recettes. Il fait face à une rupture de stock et veut se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 25 sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de la marchandise.
texts.en:
This gentleman lives in the Adidogomé neighborhood, a district of the city of Lomé. He is married to a woman who is a housewife. So as to support his family, he began selling charcoal. He has been in this business since 2006 and stocks up in Tsévié, a town in the interior of the country. He is the only one in this business in his area, which means he has a good turnover. He is about to run out of charcoal and would like to replenish his stocks, which is the reason why he is asking WAGES for his first loan to buy 25 sacks of charcoal and cover the cost of transporting this merchandise.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Kadidia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadidia B. a 30 ans et vit avec son époux et leurs deux enfants à Sanoubougou I, Kapel Kourou, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Kadidia B. pour n’avoir pas eu la chance de progresser dans les études, s’est très vite intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus. Après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, elle décida de s’initier à  l’activité d’achat et de vente d’huile alimentaire il y a environ cinq  ans. Elle mène son activité à la maison et au marché de son quartier où elle dispose d’une place. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée par sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits.
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il quelques mois. Elle  est  à son premier prêt individuel. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt,  20 bidons de 20 litres  d’huile alimentaire. Elle s’approvisionne sur commande à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) et  quelques fois dans les huileries de la place avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Kadidia B., age 30, lives with her husband and their two children in Sanoubougou I, Kapel Kourou, an outlying district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Because she never had the chance to progress in school, she soon became interested in income-generating work. After having worked in many kinds of businesses unsuccessfully, she decided about five years ago to become familiar with buying and selling cooking oil. She operates this business in her house and at the district marketplace, where she has a spot. She is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her products. To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso a few months ago. She is now on her first individual loan. With this loan, she intends to buy twenty 20-liter drums of cooking oil. She supplies herself by special order in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) and sometimes at local oil mills. And then she sells her products retail, cash or credit accepted, to customers essentially composed of women. She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help with family expenses, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cooking oil

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic U., 29 years old, is married and blessed with three children. She lives in the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City in southern part of the Philippines. She engages in peddling food like banana cue, camote cue (variations of cooked plantain rolled in sugar) and viands (tasty dishes). 

Marivic is a hardworking mother who wants to provide the needs of the family. Everyday she peddles her food to their neighborhood and nearby villages. Demand is increasing and business is getting better. That's why she wants to increase her food production.

She is planning to apply for a loan from HSPFI (a Kiva partner) amounting to Php 5,000 to purchase more ingredients and materials. This will help her meet the demands of her customers and generate a higher income. If granted, this will be Marivic's first loan with HSPFI. She is hoping that Kiva lenders will grant her application.

loans.use: To purhcase ingredients and materials for banana cue and viands

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Kouami

texts.fr: Ce monsieur a ouvert en 1992  une imprimerie, il reçoit des commandes  pour la production de calendriers, cahiers, enveloppes et divers. Actuellement il a reçu une commande pour fabriquer les feuilles d’examen, ne disposant pas suffisamment de papier, il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit qui lui permettra d’acheter des papiers et du matériel d’imprimerie afin de pouvoir exécuter la commande et satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
This gentleman opened a print shop in 1992. He gets orders to produce calendars, notebooks, envelopes and such. Presently, he has received an order to make exam booklets. Not having enough paper on hand, he is asking WAGES for his first loan which will allow him to buy paper and other material for printing so as to execute this order and satisfy his customers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of paper and other printing necessities

loans.name: Erla

texts.en: "I am the tenant of a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm, but I never stop dreaming that someday I will be able to buy my own farm. I work so hard on the farm for my family. I want to help my husband in raising our children and in providing them with a future," says Erla T., 38 years old and the mother of five children. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 15,000. She will use the loan to purchase farm materials including fertilizers and insecticides. Through her loan, she will be able to improve their harvest. CEVI aims to help small businesses grow. It provides its clients with not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase farm materials like seed, fertilizer and insecticide

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo is 39 years old and married with 4 children. She has a shop where she sells body cream, juice and drinks.  She is requesting a loan of 50,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more drinks to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Sounwonudé

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité le commerce de produits de première nécessité en détail, elle a commencé cela en 1990, la maîtrise qu’elle a de son commerce est due à son ancienneté dans ce commerce. Son stock actuel de marchandises ne lui permet pas de satisfaire ses clients. Elle voudrait se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 4 cartons de détergents « OMO », 4 cartons de lait « PEAK », 5 bidons d’huile « NIOTO », 03 cartons de savons « BF » et divers produits de premières nécessités.
Elle est mariée et a 02 enfants
texts.en:
This lady has been retailing staple items since 1990. She has been in the business for a long time and thus is well versed in it. Her present stock of merchandise does not allow her to satisfy the needs of her customers. She would like to stock up and is thus asking WAGES for her first loan to buy 4 cases of detergents (brand: Omo), 4 cases of milk (brand: Peak), 5 cans of oil (brand: Nioto) , 3 cases of soap (brand: BF) and various other staple goods. She is married and has 2 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of staple goods for re-sale

loans.name: 14-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Xuân Hắc Thị (84) is a 65-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Xuân is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 14-Nam Ngạn (17-07-14).

Xuân is married and has 3 adult children. To making a living, Xuân owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale. Xuân has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1,200,000 Vietnamese Dong (about US $67) a month from these activities.

In 2007, Xuân joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Xuân has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,442,900 dong from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 dong which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. The loan will be the 4th loan she has taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Xuân plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. N. Thị Hội (83) is a 60-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 dong loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

2. P. Thị Hà (88) is a 42-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 dong loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

3. Lê Thị Hảo (114) is a 27-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 dong loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

4. N. Thị Lan (116) is a 47-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 dong loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Xuân Hắc Thị (84) là 65 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Xuân là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 14-Nam Ngạn (17-07-14).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán. Xuân thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Xuân kiếm được khoảng 1.200.000 VND. Vào 2007, Xuân đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Xuân đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 2.442.900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1. N. Thị Hội (83) là 60 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

2. P. Thị Hà (88) là 42 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.

3. Lê Thị Hảo (114) là 27 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

4. N. Thị Lan (116) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

*Note: Many FPW borrowers have expressed a desire to borrow larger amounts to make more significant investments in their businesses. In response to this, FPW has recently added a new loan product of 6,000,000 dong with a 20 month term to its Thanh Hoa City branch portfolio.

loans.use: For baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Riskat

texts.en: Riskat is 39 years old and married with four children. She sells sarongs of various colors to her customers.  She is requesting a loan of 60,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more sarongs to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Amé

texts.fr: Cette femme est une jeune célibataire qui exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes et de tissus, elle est très dynamique et travailleuse, elle fait son commerce de façon ambulante et approche les clients dans leur maison pour leur vendre des pagnes, elle vend aussi à crédit à ses fidèles clients et récupère son argent dans les huit jours ou dans 2 semaines. Elle veut rehausser son stock, elle sollicite pour cela son premier crédit pour acheter 12 pièces de pagnes « UNIWAX ».
texts.en:
This young lady is single and sells "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) and other kinds of cloth. She is very energetic and hard-working. She sells her goods on foot, meeting her customers at their doorsteps to sell "pagnes". She also sells on credit to her faithful customers and then comes to get paid a week to 2 weeks later. She wants to add to her inventory and is thus requesting her first loan to buy 12 lengths of "Uniwax" brand "pagne".

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "pagnes" and other types of cloth for re-sale

loans.name: Yawa

texts.fr: Résidente du quartier d’adéwui à Lomé, cette femme est mariée et à 2 enfants. Son mari est un  ouvrier au port autonome de Lomé et son revenu est insuffisant pour couvrir toutes les charges du foyer. Pour aider son mari, elle a débuté le commerce de pagnes en 2007. Elle fait ce commerce de façon ambulante. Elle veut agrandir son activité. Elle a déjà obtenu un prêt de WAGES qu’elle a bien remboursé, elle sollicite son deuxième cycle de prêt pour acheter 25 pièces de pagnes de différentes qualités.
texts.en:
A resident of the Adéwui neighborhood in Lomé, this woman is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a workman in the autonomous port of Lomé and his income is insufficient to cover all the household expenses. To help her husband, she began selling "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) in 2007. She does this work on foot. She would like to expand her business. She has already had one loan from WAGES that she reimbursed correctly. She is now asking for her second loan to buy 25 lengths of "pagne" of varying qualities.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "pagnes" for re-sale

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo is 45 years old and married with two children. She has a shop where she sells drinks at retail to her customers.  She is requesting a loan of 60,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more drinks to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Prum

texts.en:
Prum S. is a 39-year-old woman who lives with another family member in Siem Reap Province. She has rented a market store where she sells duck eggs and chicken eggs to earn a living. She and her husband usually go to buy eggs in bulk at the cheapest price possible from rural people whose houses are full of poultry they raise for eggs.

Recently, the family's living conditions have not been comfortable because their house is surrounded by pollutants, which is harmful to their health. Therefore, Prum S. is requesting a loan to purchase another piece of land. With the other half of the loan she will build a restroom for her family's sanitation.

loans.use: To buy another piece of land and to build a restroom for the family

loans.name: Bashiru

texts.en: Bashiru is 60 years old and married with ten children. He has a drinking bar where he sells drinks to make a living.  He is requesting  a loan of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more drinks to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Kunle

texts.en: R. is 26 years old and married with two children. She sells provisions and drinks.  She is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more provisions to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Benkadi 2 De N’Tjila Group

texts.fr:
A majorité  des femmes mariées ayant en moyenne 28 ans, 3 enfants et vivant dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, enfants et époux,  Benkadi 2 est un regroupement du village de N’tjila de la  préfecture de Bougouni, région de Sikasso (république du Mali)
 Elles se sont connues par des relations associatives hivernales. Elles ont aménagé 5 hectares pour la campagne agricole dont 3 hectares pour le sorgho et  2 hectares pour l’arachide.
Afin de renforcer leur productivité agricole, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela pour faire la culture du sorgho et d’arachide.
 Elles sont à leur troisième prêt agricole et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 15 petites houes pour semer et sarcler, 80kg d’arachide graine pour la semence, directement achetées sur marché de Bougouni.  
A la récolte, elles comptent sur une production de 1 tonne 320 kg de graine d’arachide et 4,5 tonnes de sorgho. Les produits sont vendus sur le marché de Bougouni au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Avec un prix de 300FCFA, le kilogramme d’arachide et 100FCFA le kilogramme sorgho, elles espèrent obtenir un bénéfice de 40 000 FCFA chacune à la fin de la campagne qui sera utilisé selon elles dans les activités génératrices de revenus pour les faire occuper pendant la saison sèche.
texts.en:
The majority being married women having an average age of 28 and three children, living in traditional extended conjugal families with their brothers, sisters, children, and husbands, "Benkadi 2" is a group from the village of N’tjila of Bougouni prefecture, Region of Sikasso (Republic of Mali). The women know one another through off-season social ties. They have cleared five hectares for the planting season, including three hectares for sorghum and two hectares for peanuts. To bolster their agriculural production, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to grow sorghum and peanuts. They are now on their third agricultural loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. With the current loan, they intend to buy fifteen small hoes for planting and weeding and also 80 kg of peanut seeds for planting, purchased directly at the Bougouni marketplace. Upon harvest, they are planning on a production of 1.32 tonnes of peanuts and 4.5 tonnes of sorghum. The produce is sold in cash at the Bougouni marketplace. Their customers are composed of men and women. With a price of 300 francs CFA per kilo for peanuts and 100 francs a kilo for sorghum, the group members each hope to obtain a profit of 40,000 francs at the end of the crop year. Their profits will accordingly be used in revenue-generating work to keep them busy during the dry season.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy minor supplies and equipment for farming and planting

loans.name: Bola

texts.en: Bola is 44 years old and married with two children. She sells sarongs and is requesting the loan of N60,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Seema Gul

texts.en: Seema Gul is a daughter of A. A.. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan, with a large family. Seema Gul wants to take out a loan for her husband's fruit and vegetable shop. Seema Gul's husband wants to improve his business and enlarge it. So she requested an individual loan of 30000 Afghani. She is happy that there is this nice process that can solve the entrepreneurs’ problems.

loans.use: For expanding business

loans.name: Son's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Son S. is a borrower who has been recruited to be leader of the group loan by the other borrowers.

Son S. is a 45-year-old widowed woman, and is the mother of five children, three of whom are employed at different jobs: her first child is a carpenter; the second child is a massage staff person; and the third child works as a chef in a restaurant.

At present, Son S. sells a few snack cakes and desserts to the neighbors who live near her house in the village. Because the family's house is too old and often breaks down, Son S. has decided to seek a loan on Kiva in order to hire a housing repairer to repair her old house.

The other borrowers who are jointly taking this loan are:

C., a single lady, who sells fish and vegetables in the market. She is applying for a loan as business capital to increase the size of her business.

N., who will be using her loan to repair her old house and to use as capital in her business of selling food.

loans.use: To hire a housing repairer to repair her old house

loans.name: Benkadi  1 De  N’Tjila Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 1 est composé de  dix femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans et de 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles avec leurs frères, sœurs, enfants et époux dans le village de N’tjila qui relève de la préfecture de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues par des relations d’activités agricoles. Elles comptent exploiter pendant cette campagne hivernale, 4 hectares d’arachide et 2 hectares de riz. 
Afin d’augmenter leur productivité pour satisfaire leurs besoins alimentaires et pécuniaires, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt agricole et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt ces femmes comptent acheter,  des semences (100kg de graine d’arachide et 70kg de riz non décortiqué), 10 bidons d’herbicides, 15 sacs d’engrais (dont 10 sacs d’urée et 5 sacs de complexes). Les semences et les intrants sont achetés auprès des commerçants de Bougouni.
La production attendue est de 2 tonnes 640 kg de graine d’arachide  et 5 tonnes de riz Les produits sont vendus sur le marché de Bougouni à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en gros, en détail  et au comptant. 
Avec ce prêt, les membres du groupe Benkadi 1 envisagent réaliser un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA chacune à la fin du cycle qui leurs permettra  de faire face aux frais de santé de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi 1 is composed of six married women who have an average age of 28 and five children. They live in traditional conjugal families with their brothers, sisters, children, and husbands in the village of N’tjila, which belongs to Bougouni prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through agricultural work. In this crop year, they intend to plant four hectares of peanuts and two hectares of rice. To increase their productivity for satisfying their financial and food needs, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their third agricultural loan. All the preceding loans have been repaid. With this new loan, they intend to buy seeds (100 kg of peanuts and 70 kg of unpolished rice), ten drums of herbicides, fifteen sacks of manure (including ten sacks of urea and five sacks of complexes). The seeds and other supplies are purchased from Bougouni merchants. The harvest expected is 2.64 tonnes of peanuts and 5 tonnes of rice. The produce is sold retail and wholesale at the Bougouni marketplace to customers composed of men and women, in cash transactions. With this loan, the group members each envision realizing a profit of 35,000 francs CFA at the end of the cycle, allowing them to address the health care costs for their children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and agricultural supplies

loans.name: Djiguiya 1  De   Kola (Koumantou) Group

texts.fr:
Composé de dix femmes mariées, les membres du groupe Djiguiya 1 du village de Kola ont une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et de 6 enfants. Elles  vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies. Le village de Kola relève de la commune rurale de Koumantou, préfecture de Bougouni (région de Sikasso,  république du Mali). 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations familiales et de voisinages. 
Pour soutenir leurs activités agricoles en ressource financière afin d’améliorer leur productivité, elles ont  décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt agricole et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 150 kg de semence d’arachide et s’acquitter des frais de labour de 6 hectares dont 2 hectares pour l’arachide et 4 hectares pour le maïs. Les semences sont achetées sur le marché de Koumantou lors des foires hebdomadaires.
Ces femmes  comptent sur une production de 1 tonne 750 kg  de graine d’arachide  et 14 tonnes de maïs. Avec une clientèle  composée essentiellement de revendeurs et de quelques consommateurs, les produits sont vendus en gros, détail et au comptant sur les marchés de Bougouni et de Koumantou. 
Avec ce prêt les femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice de 50 000 FCFA chacune à la fin de la campagne agricole qui les servira à s’investir dans l’élevage des ovins.
texts.en:
Composed of six married women, the members of the group Djiguiya 1, of the village of Kola, have an average age of 37 and six children. They live in traditional extended conjugal families. The village of Kola belongs to the rural community of Koumantou, Bougouni prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know one another by family and community ties. To support their agricultural businesses with financial resources, in order to improve their productivity, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their third agricultural loan. All the preceding loans have been repaid. With this new loan, they intend to buy 150 kg of seeds for growing peanuts and to pay for the cost of labor for six hectares, including two hectares for peanuts and four hectares for corn. The seeds are purchased at the Koumantou marketplace during weekly fairs. These women are planning on a production of 1.75 tonnes of peanuts and 14 tonnes of corn. With a customer base composed essentially of retailers and a few consumers, they sell their products wholesale and retail, and in cash transaction, at the markets of Bougouni and Koumantou. With this loan, the women hope to obtain a profit if 50,000 francs CFA at the end of the crop year. The profits will be invested in raising sheep.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds for planting peanuts and to pay for labor (peanuts and corn)

loans.name: Djiguiya 2 De  Diossébougou.(Koumantou) Group

texts.fr:
Vivant en majorité dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, toutes les femmes du groupe Djiguiya 2 sont mariées avec une moyenne  d’âge de 38 ans et de 7 enfants. Elles résident dans le  village de Diossébougou, dans la commune rurale de Koumantou (région de Sikasso en république du Mali).
A travers des relations agricoles et de parenté elles se sont connues. Elles exploitent plus de six hectares par campagnes en diverses cultures.(maïs, arachide, sorgho petit mil, pois de terre etc.). 
Pour redynamiser leurs relations et augmenter leur productivité agricole, ces femmes ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
 Elles sont à leur troisième prêt agricole et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Ce prêt servira à acheter, 20 daba pour les semis et le sarclage, 50 kg de semence d’arachide et 12 sacs d’engrais (dont 4 sacs de complexe et 8 sacs d’urée) tout cela pour faire 1,5 hectare d’arachide, 3 hectares de sorgho et 2 hectares de petit mil. Les produits sont achetés auprès des commerçants grossistes de Koumantou. La production attendue est de, 1 tonne 155 kg de graine d’arachide, 7 tonnes 500kg pour le sorgho et  4 tonnes  pour le petit mil. En fin de campagne, les récoltes sont vendues en détail, en gros et au comptant sur les marchés de Bougouni et Koumantou à une  clientèle  composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice de 50 000 FCFA chacune en fin de campagne qui  servira à entretenir leurs enfants.
texts.en:
Mostly living in extended traditional families, the women of the Djiguiya 2 group are all married and have an average age of 38 with, on average, 7 children. They reside in the village of Diossébougou, in the rural community of Koumantou (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali).

They met through farming or through being related to each other. They cultivate more than 6 hectares each season with diverse crops (maize, peanuts, sorghum, native millet, potatoes, etc.). In order to enliven their relationships and increase their agricultural productivity, these women decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their third rural loan and both the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

This loan will be used to buy 20 "daba" hoes for planting and weeding, 50 kg of peanut seeds and 12 sacks of fertilizer (that is, 4 sacks of complex fertilizer and 8 sacks of urea), all this with the intention of cultivating 1.5 hectares of peanuts, 3 hectares of sorghum, and 2 hectares of native millet. The products will be purchased from the wholesalers in Koumantou. The expected yield is 1 ton 155 kg of shelled peanuts, 7 tons 500 kg of sorghum and 4 tons of native millet. After the harvest, the produce will be sold retail or wholesale, for cash, at the markets of Bougouni and Koumangou to a clientele composed of men and women.

They each expect to make a profit of 50,000 F CFA at the end of the planting season, which will be used to support their children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of seeds, minor agricultural material, and entrants

loans.name: Djiguiya  2  De Kola (Koumantou) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiya 2 est constitué de dix  femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et  5 enfants. C’est dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies que ces dames vivent avec leurs frères, sœurs, enfants et époux dans le village de Kola (commune rurale de Koumantou), préfecture de Bougouni, région de Sikasso, république du Mali. 
A travers des liens de mariage et d’activités agricoles, ces femmes se sont connues. 
Afin d’améliorer leur productivité, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt agricole et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 25 sacs d’engrais dont 9 sacs de complexe et 16 sacs d’urée  pour faire 3 hectares de maïs, 1,5 hectare de sorgho, et 1hectare de haricot. 
La production attendue à l’hectare est de 3,5 tonnes pour le maïs, 1,5 tonne de sorgho et 1 tonne pour le haricot. Les intrants sont achetés auprès des commerçants de Bougouni et des forains fréquentant la foire de Koumantou. 
En fin de campagne, les femmes du groupe espèrent sur un bénéfice de 50 000FCFA chacune qu’elles vont investir dans le maraîchage avant la prochaine campagne.
texts.en:
This Djiguiya 2 group is made up of 10 married women, who have an average age of 36 with, on average, 5 children. They live in traditional extended (conjugal) families with their brothers, sisters, children and husbands, in the village of Kola, in the rural community of Koumantou, prefecture of Bougouni, Sikasso region, Republic of Mali.

They met through farming or through being related to each other by marriage. So as to improve their productivity, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their third rural loan and both the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed. With this loan they intend to buy 25 sacks of fertilizer, of which 9 will be complex fertilizer and 16 sacks of urea to plant 3 hectares of maize, 1.5 hectares of sorghum, and 1 hectare of beans. The expected yield is 3.5 tons of maize, 1.5 tons of sorghum, and 1 ton of beans. The fertilizer is purchased from the merchants in Bougouni and from itinerant merchants at the market fairs of Koumantou. At the end of the harvest season, each of the women expects to make a profit of 50,000 F CFA, which they will invest in market gardening before the next major agricultural season.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of agricultural entrants for their crops

loans.name: Taibatu

texts.en: Taibatu is 40 years old and married with three children. She sells medicines, jewelry and drinks.  She is requesting the loan of N80,000 to purchase more medicines and jewelry to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouma  Sedougou N’Tjila Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabougnouma est composé de dix femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles dans la village de Sedougou -N’tjila qui relève de la commune rurale de Koumantou, préfecture de Bougouni, région de Sikasso, république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce et d’activités agricoles. 
Afin d’augmenter leur ressource financière en vu de  mieux rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, ces femmes du groupe Sabougnouma ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt agricole et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, des semences d’arachide, 8  sacs d’urée et 10 bidons d’herbicides auprès  des commerçants de Bougouni et des forains de Koumantou. 
La  production est estimée à 3 tonnes d’arachide graine qui sera écoulée dans les différents marchés de Koumantou et environs, au comptant,  en détail et à crédit aux revendeurs et aux consommateurs.
Avec ce prêt ces femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice de 45.000FCFA chacune en fin de campagne qu’elles  investirons dans l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The Sabougnouma group is composed of 10 married women who have an average age of 32 and 4 children, on average. They live in traditional conjugal families in the village of Sedougou-N’tjila which belongs to the rural community of Koumantou, prefecture of Bougouni, Sikasso region, Republic of Mali. These women met by working or farming together.

So as to expand their financial resources and in view of making their agricultural businesses more profitable, the women of the Sabougnouma group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their third agricultural loan with both the preceding ones correctly reimbursed.

This loan will be used to buy peanut seeds, 8 sacks of urea, and 10 cans of herbicide from the merchants of Bougouni and the itinerant merchants of Koumantou. The yield is estimated at 3 tons of shelled peanuts which will be sold in the various markets of Koumantou and surroundings, for cash, retail and for credit to middlemen and consumers.

With this loan, each of the women expects to make a profit of 45,000 F CFA at the end of the farming season, which they intend to invest in raising sheep and goats.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of seed, fertilizer, and herbicides

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is 42 years old and married with a child. She has a shop where she sells medicines to make a living. She is requesting the loan of N80,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badenya est composé majoritairement de femmes mariées vivant dans des familles polygamiques avec en moyenne 44 ans et 2 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Darsalam de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali) et se sont connues à travers de liens de voisinage, d’amitié, de mariage et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle.
Elles ont connu Soro Yiriwaso à travers une cliente du prêt solidaire qui mène les mêmes activités génératrices de revenus qu’elles au marché de Médine. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers tels les habits brodés, les pagnes wax, l’encens, les chaussures etc. 
En vu d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles se sont organisées pour adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution. Elles  sont à leur 5ème prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé les prêts antérieurs. 
Ce nouveau  prêt servira à acheter, 4 pièces de bazin riche qui seront teintés avant d’être vendu, 150 paires de chaussure, 10 douzaines de parfums et de la matière première pour la préparation de l’encens (5kg de magnonkissèni, 5kg de n’guéni et un carton de parfums). Pour avoir une bonne qualité d’encens on imbibe  le magnonkissèni ou le n’guéni dans l’eau de Cologne  pendant un mois au moins avant d’assaisonner avec les autres qualités de parfums. Elles se ravitaillent toutes en matières premières à Ségou  au grand marché et effectuent leurs ventes au comptant, en détail et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant dans les quartiers et au grand marché  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 39.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour aider les époux à la prise en charge des dépenses familiales.  
Elles ont pour ambition de devenir des fournisseurs dans les différentes activités qu’elles mènent.
texts.en:
This Badenya group is made up mostly of married women living in polygamous families with an average age of 44 and on average, 2 children. They all live in the Darsalam neighborhood of the town of Ségou (4the administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through ties of neighborhood, friendship, marriage and through belonging to the same traditional association.

They learned about Soro Yiriwaso from a solidarity-loan client who has the same sort of business they do in the marketplace of Médine. They sell various items such as embroidered clothing, "wax-brand pagnes" (high quality lengths of brightly printed African cloth), incense, shoes, etc.

In the intention of increasing their working capital, they got organized to join our loan program. They are on their 5th solidarity loan, after having correctly reimbursed the preceding loans. This new loan will be used to buy 4 bolts of high-quality "bazin" (a sort of damask) which will be dyed before being sold, 150 pairs of shoes, 10 dozen perfumes and raw materials for making incense (5kg of "magnonkissèni" and 5kg of "n’guéni"--seeds of wild exotic plants--and a case of perfumes). To have good quality incense you soak the "magnonkissèni" or the "n’guéni" in eau de Cologne for a month or more before using other sorts of perfumes to embellish it. They buy all the raw materials in Ségou in the big open-air market and sell their wares for cash and retail or for credit out of their homes and walking through the neighborhoods and the big marketplace, to a clientele composed of men and women.

They expect to make a monthly average profit of 39,000 F CFA which will be used to help their husbands support their families. Their ambition is to become big-time suppliers of the various items they sell.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles to make incense etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Seymur

texts.en:
This man was born in 1979. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Djabrayil region, now settled in Khirdalan town.

Seymur is married, has one child. Four years ago he started his taxi business. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy spare parts for his car to improve his taxi business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Benkadi sont mariés majoritairement dans des familles monogamiques avec en moyenne 31ans et 2 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Darsalam de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers de liens de voisinage, de mariage et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle.
Ce groupe fait le commerce d’articles divers tels les pagnes wax, les parfums, les chaussures, les céréales (mil, riz et haricot) etc.
Après 4 prêts solidaires tous correctement remboursés, elles sont à leur  5 eme  prêt qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 4 sacs de riz, 21 pièces de pagne wax, 13 douzaines de parfums et 30 paires de chaussures. Elles se ravitaillent en riz à Molodo et N’Débougou, en pagnes wax, parfums et chaussures au Burkina Faso. Leurs marchandises sont revendues au comptant, en détail et à crédit  en ambulant dans les différents marchés et de porte en porte à Ségou à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000FCFA qu’elles comptent utiliser pour la prise en charge des frais de santé et de la scolarité des enfants.
Elles ont pour ambition de devenir des grossistes dans la vente des produits cosmétiques au grand marché de Ségou.
texts.en:
The five members of the Benkadi group are mainly married and living in monogamous families. They have an average age of 31 and two children each. They all live in the Darsalam district of Ségou (Mali’s fourth administrative region) and met each other through neighborhood ties, marriage and by belonging to the same traditional association. The group sells miscellaneous items such as wax cloth, perfume, shoes and cereals (millet, rice and beans). After four solidarity loans, all repaid in full, they are now on their fifth loan which will be used to buy four bags of rice, 21 pieces of wax cloth, 13 dozen perfumes and 30 pairs of shoes. They get their supplies of rice in Molodo and N’Débougou, and wax cloth, perfume and shoes in Burkina Faso. Their clientele is made up of men and women, and they sell their merchandise at retail prices for cash or credit by walking around the various markets and by going door to door in Ségou. They hope to make an average monthly profit of CFA 50,000, which they plan to use for healthcare expenses and the children’s school fees. Their goal is to become wholesalers of cosmetics in Ségou’s main market.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy miscellaneous goods

loans.name: Nyètaa Group

texts.fr:
Avec en moyenne 38 ans et 6 enfants, les membres du groupe Nyètaa (une veuve et 3 femmes mariées) vivent dans des familles monogamiques dans le quartier Darsalam de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers de liens de voisinage, de mariage et professionnels.
Ce groupe fait le commerce d’articles divers tels les plastiques, les pagnes, les habits pour enfants, les draps de lit etc. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur  5ème prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé les prêts précédents. 
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 64 pièces de pagne wax et 6 douzaines de seaux en plastiques. Elles se ravitaillent en pagnes wax au grand marché de Bamako (capitale du Mali), Ségou et Lomé (république de Togo), quant aux seaux en plastiques à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou auprès des grossistes. Leurs marchandises sont revendues  au comptant, en détail et à crédit en ambulant dans les différents marchés et de porte en porte à Ségou à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 48.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt et pour contribuer aux évènements sociaux. 
Elles ont pour ambition de devenir grossistes pour ravitailler les détaillants de la place.
texts.en:
With an average age of 38 and six children each, the members of the Nyètaa group (one widow and three married women) live in monogamous families in the Darsalam district of Ségou (Mali’s fourth administrative region) and know each other through neighborhood ties, marriage and business. The group sells miscellaneous items such as plastic buckets, traditional African cloth (pagnes), children’s clothing and bed sheets. In order to meet the needs of their customers, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso’s loan program. They are on their fifth solidarity loan, having successfully repaid all previous loans. The latest loan will be used to buy 64 pieces of wax cloth and six dozen plastic buckets. They get their supplies of wax cloth at the main market in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and in Ségou and Lomé (Republic of Togo). They buy the plastic buckets from wholesalers at the weekly fair in Ségou. Their clientele is made up of men and women, and they sell their merchandise at retail prices for cash or credit by walking around the various markets and by going door to door in Ségou. They hope to make an average monthly profit of CFA 48,000 which will be used to repay the loan and to help pay for social events. Their ambition is to become wholesalers to supply local retailers.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wax cloth and plastic buckets

loans.name: Abdumalik

texts.ru:
Мавлонов Абдумалик молодой предприниматель, который продвигает свою жизнь при помощи дохода с продажи мужской обуви.  Он привозит товар с Бишкека раз в месяц.
На следующий кредит он планирует привезти летние шлёпанцы. У Абдумалика стабильная торговля и оборотный капитал. Мавлонов доволен всеми условиями Фонда и рад сотрудничать.
texts.en:
Abdumalik M. is a young businessman who makes his way with income earned by selling men's shoes. He brings in his goods from Bishkek once a month. With this loan, he plans to import summer slippers. Abdumalik has a stable business and working capital. M. is happy with all of the loan terms and is glad to cooperate with us.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling shoes

loans.name: Umarjon

texts.en: U. Umarjon is 41 years old, married, with three children. He has had a butcher shop, running a meat selling business for nine years. He provides the markets with meat and his family with necessary food. Now Umarjon is requesting a loan of $2,200. Due to the profitability of his business, the determination of this micro-entrepreneur, and his experience in the business, this customer is qualified to receive this loan. He is counting on your help. Your support will really help him. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchasing cattle for his butcher shop

loans.name: Uktamjon

texts.en:
M. Uktamjon is 24 years old, married, and has a little child. He is the sole breadwinner for his family and his only income comes from the raising and sale of large livestock at the local market. Every year, he buys young heifers from the farms in adjacent villages. He raises them with the help of his wife and then sells the adult cows and bulls to local butchers.

Today, Uktamjon is thinking about expanding his business, since the income from his present herd isn't enough to provide for his family. He plans to purchase additional young cattle. To do this, he needs to invest an additional 4,000 Somoni in his business. In order to receive this amount, Uktamjon has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner organization, IMON International.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit:  www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cattle in order to expand his business

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du  groupe Tièssiri sont toutes mariées dans des familles monogames avec un âge moyen de 26 ans et  2 enfants. Elles habitent dans  le quartier Darsalam  de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Ce groupe excelle dans l’achat vente  des céréales, des parfums, de l’encens et de la friperie.
Pour augmenter le volume de leurs activités génératrices de revenus, elles ont  décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui elles  sont à leur premier prêt solidaire. 
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter,  3 sacs de riz, un sac d’arachide, 1 sac de haricot, 2 cartons de parfums, un colis de friperie, 50 kg de magnonkissèni et de n’guéni  à la foire hebdomadaire du grand marché de Ségou. Elles revendent toutes leurs marchandises en détail  au comptant et à crédit,  à domicile et en ambulant dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent  réaliser  un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 28.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  aider les maris à la prise en charge des dépenses familiales.  
Elles ont pour ambition d’augmenter le volume de leurs activités à partir de leur collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The four women in the Tièssiri group are all married and live in monogamous families, with an average age of 26 and two children each. They live in the Darsalam district of Ségou (Mali’s fourth administrative region). The group excels at buying and selling cereals, perfume, incense and used clothing. To increase their volume of revenue-generating business they decided to join the loan program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their first solidarity loan. This loan will be used to buy three bags of rice, one bag of peanuts, one bag of beans, two boxes of perfume, one bundle of used clothing and 50kg of magnonkissèni and n’guéni (seeds from exotic plants) at the weekly fair in Ségou’s main marketplace. Their clientele is made up of men and women, and they sell their merchandise at retail, either for cash or credit, in their own homes or by walking around the neighborhood. They expect to make an average monthly profit of CFA 28,000 which will be used to help their husbands take care of the family expenses. Their goal is to increase their volume of business through their collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy miscellaneous items

loans.name: Salim

texts.en: A livestock breeder for eight years, S. Salim was born in 1968 in Khujand, Tajikistan. He is married and responsible for three people including his wife and two children. Very dynamic, serious, and entrepreneurial, he is proposing to expand his flock and repair his enclosure. This will enable him to meet the needs of a rather large clientele from his village and its neighborhood, some of whom buy animals from more than 20 km from his village. With this goal in mind, Salim is requesting a loan that will serve him as business capital. The profit he will make from this business will allow him to improve living conditions for his household and also make some investments. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more small cattle for his developing business

loans.name: Manzura

texts.ru: Болтуева Манзура 1970 года рождения , замужем , имеет 2 детей.  Муж Манзуры  работает водителем маршурутного такси. Одному трудно кормить семью. Посоветовавшись  с мужем Манзура решила получить кредит для откорма скота. Она уже содержит скот более 6 лет. Первый кредит получила на покупку  овец. Со временем , когда бызнес расцветал, она получила повторный кредит на покупки коров. Сейчас благодаря КИВА, Манзура  дома содержит несколько овец и несколько коров.  Она сотрудничает с Микроинвест 2006 года.
texts.en:
Manzura B., born in 1970, is married and has two children. Manzura's husband works as a minibus driver, but its hard for him alone to support the family. After discussing it with her husband, Manzura decided to obtain a loan for raising livestock. She has already had livestock for over six years. Her first loan was for buying sheep. With time, as the business thrived, she received another loan for buying cows. Now thanks to KIVA, Manzura keeps several sheep and several cows at home. She has been a Microinvest client since 2006.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising livestock

loans.name: Alijon

texts.en: O. Alijon is a hard-working farmer because he knows that the only way he can support and provide for his loved-ones is through hard work and dedication. Consequently, he leaves home every day at dawn to work on his farm and to look after his cattle. Alijon wishes to expand his business by purchasing young cattle and fodder for them. That is the reason that he is asking for a loan. Alijon will always cherish the memory of all those who gave him a helping hand when he needed it by granting him his request. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.
