Lanie is a micro-entrepreneur, presently engaged in selling vegetables from the harvest of the vegetable garden that her husband, a farmer, cultivates. This vegetable garden and small riceland supports her 6 children who are still dependent on her. In times of no harvest, she also buys vegetables from neighbors who are engaged in similar gardening. She started this vegetable ‘buy and sell’ business at the time she got married with an initial capital of only PHP 1,500. Now her business is still existing and stable. She decided to join PAGLAUM MPC because of the benefits and other services that the Co-op has offered for the members. As a first time borrower, she is applying for an amount of PHP 3,000, under the Medal Pangnegosyo 2 program, to add her vegetable vending business. She is prioritizing her children’s education for their good future.

loans.use: Addional capital for her vegetable vending business.

location.town: Calabayan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental, Mindan

loans.name: Herminia

texts.en:
Herminio G., previously, was a security guard. Now, he is a farmer. He grows rice to feed his family and to provide all his children with an education. He has already been tilling the farm for 15 years. His business has helped him buy the things they need like electricity, food, water and to pay school fees.

He is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and insecticides. The loan will really help him increase his yield. 

CEVI has been providing financial services to the poor. CEVI provides their clients with not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Mrs. Susana A. is 52 years old, married to Mr. Rogelio A. and blessed with 2 children. She became a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative under the PDP-LP program last April 16, 2007. Her one child is already married and the other one is working in Dubai. Currently, she's requesting a loan in the amount of 18,000 as additional capital for her existing project, which is a sari-sari store. She just hopes that her sari-sari store will become mini-grocery someday. And for her family, she hopes that someday also they could build a new house.

loans.use: To provide additional capital for sari-sari store.

loans.name: Ariel

texts.en:
Ariel F. is a farmer. He grows rice to be able to provide for the needs of his family. Ariel is 25 years old this year. He has been tilling land for three years already. Because of his farm, he has been able to pay the school fees and for other expenses in their home. 

He would like to ask for a loan of PHP 8,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. The loan will help him improve and develop his business even more. 

CEVI has been providing financial services to the poor. CEVI gives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides for farming.

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en:
Mrs Sreng C., aged 54, was married in 1980 and has six children: one daughter, married but living inside the family home, and five sons. Four of her sons attend school and the other son runs a battery-charging business in front of his house. The family lives in a small village across the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sreng has been selling mangoes for over ten years – she buys them on contract from villagers and resells them at Phnom Penh market. Sreng’s daughter has been a hairdresser for five years. She wants to raise pigs in her free time, but she lacks money to purchase piglets to raise. Therefore Sreng is applying for a loan of $500 USD in order to help fund her daughter's initiative.

loans.use: To purchase baby pigs to raise

loans.name: Sarum

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarum C., 50, and her husband, Mr. Phoeuk Chhum, 52, live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers north of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1979 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Two of her children are married and now live outside the family home, and the other two children study in Art College in Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sarum has been selling grocery items for many years, purchasing them from a market in Phnom Penh for resale at her shop in front of her house. She also buys mangoes on contract from her villagers for resale. Her husband is a farmer growing bananas, bitter gourds, and ridge gourds on his farm near the house. Sarum is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase mangoes from villagers for resale in the market and more grocery items for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase mangoes for resale in the market and more grocery items for her shop.

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Mrs Agustina O. is a 70-year-old widow with one married child. She is a resident of Mapang Rizal, Zamboanga del Norte. Mrs O. has operated a sari-sari ('various kinds') store at their home for almost five years. She started the business with her own capital from the monthly pension she receives as a retired teacher.

Mrs O. heard that Kiva partner, Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC), offered a pensioners' loan so she visited their office for some information. She was interested in joining because of the insurance benefit. So on November 20, 2007, she became an associate member of PMPC under the Program for Pensioners. She availed herself of the opportunity to take a loan. Through PMPC Mrs O. was able to expand her business by adding a fruit stall as an extension of her sari-sari store.

She is now requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP for the additional purchase of grocery stocks and fruits. Mrs O. is very happy operating her business, and her only dream is that her business will grow and continue to support her in the future.

loans.use: To purchase grocery stocks and fruits

loans.name: Rudilyn

texts.en:
Rudilyn S. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 42 years old. Rudilyn is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Rudilyn owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. She sells grilled pork and poultry products in the local community.  Rudilyn has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Rudilyn joined PMPC. Rudilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. Rudilyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP. These funds will be used to purchase more raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Rudilyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients for food business.

loans.name: Marly

texts.en:
"My husband and I have been farming since the start of our marriage. We have been tilling the land for 12 years already. We use the 2 and 3/4 hectare farm to buy the things that we need," says Marly L., 39-year old mother of four children.

She would like to ask for a loan of PHP 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and chemicals. In doing so, she thinks that her loan will help increase their harvest. 

CEVI provides financial services to the poor. CEVI gives not just loans but trainings and insurance as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals for farming.

loans.name: Elvera

texts.en:
Elvera C. is from the village of DUMAGOC. She is 47 years old. Elvera is married and has 3 school-aged children. Elvera owns & operates a fishing business. She sells ocean-caught fish in the local community. Elvera has been in this business for 4 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Elvera has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. This 2nd loan of PHP 7000 will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Her business financially supports the immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.

loans.name: Soklay’S Group

texts.en:
Mr. Soklay Cheav (shown in the picture his wife and group members) was selected to be a group leader for a loan from Maxima. In the group there are three families, including him. All the group's members live along National Road Number Two, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

1-Mr. Soklay Cheav, 54, and his wife, Mrs. Nara Sor, 48, were married in 1983 and have four children: one son and three daughters. One of their children is married and lives away from the family, two children have full time employment and the youngest one studies in the local school. Soklay has been driving a motor taxi since 1986, while his wife stays at home. Soklay is requesting a $300 loan to purchase a new motorbike, to replace the old one, for his sons for commuting to work.

2-Mrs. Sopheap K., 38, and her husband, Mr. Rithy Sem, 44, were married in 1987 and have two sons and two daughters. In the past, she stayed at home to take care of her children. She now raises pigs at home. Mr. Rithy Sem has been driving motor taxi for ten years. He drives in Phnom Penh. Sopheap is requesting a loan of $300 loan to purchase pig feed.

3-Mrs. Srey-on K., 26, and her husband, Mr. Senghoir Taing, 32, were married in 2003 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. All of the children are still young. She has been a garment factory worker for over ten years. Her husband has been driving a motor taxi for over five years. As well, he drives in Phnom Penh. Srey-on’s mother sells fertilizer. She wants to expand her business, but she doesn’t have enough capital. So, Srey-on is requesting a loan of $200 to help fund her mother’s business.

loans.use: To replace a motorbike to the new one for his sons to drive to work.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Mrs. T., residing at Sapang Dalaga, has been a regular member of Paglaum MPC for almost two years. She has a happy married life and is blessed with three children. Her husband is a motorcycle driver who can also help to support their family's needs.

Mrs. T. is thankful to Paglaum because, through the Co-op, she was able to obtain a loan in the amount of 4,000 that will be used as additional capital for her snack-vending business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for food preparation for her business

loans.name: Davaasuren

texts.en:
Davaasuren D. lives with his wife and two teenage children in Arhanghay, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His two sons are high school students.

Davaasuren has a small carpentry business. He makes furniture and other wooden household items. He started his business in 2006 with 50,000 MNT ($1 USD=1,450 MNT). From the beginning, his business has done quite well and his capital has increased to 2,000,000 MNT. He mostly sells his handmade furniture to herder families in the countryside. Sometimes he barters his furniture in exchange for sheep and goats. He usually obtains requests for new furniture from families in the town because of the high quality and design of his products.

In the future, he would like to focus on the quality of his products, which Davaasuren values very much. He requests a loan to purchase wood for his business.

loans.use: Purchase woods to build furniture.

loans.name: Rengie

texts.en:
Rengie V. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 27 years old, married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Rengie owns and operates a business involving computers and ink toner refilling. While not her only means for generating revenue, her main source of income is from her internet cafe. Rengie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Rengie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC to purchase equipment to improve her business. Rengie is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP to purchase equipment. This loan will be her third taken from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

------------------------- About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase equipment.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn, 41, is the mother of four children. She lives in Mutia, Zamboanga del Norte. Her children are school-aged: two are in college and the others are in high school and elementary school.

She is engaged in buying and selling copra and charcoal to earn enough income for the family. Her husband is a farmer.

In 2006, Marilyn decided to become a member of Paglaum Coop, to accessed a loan for her existing business. During her membership, she successfully paid her loans diligently. She is accessed her third loan in the amount of Php 50,000, to harvest coconut farm land owned by a neighbor, to generate additional income to support the education of her children.

loans.use: Harvest coconut farm land.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth C. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 51 years old, married mother of six school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a manufacturing business. The main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing and selling products, especially curtains to local businesses and community members. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elizabeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products.

Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Elizabeth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

--------------------------------------- About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials to manufacture products.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel D., 24, is from the village of Katipunan, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is married and has one infant-aged child.

To make a living, Maricel owns and operates a business raising crops. Her main source of income comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Maricel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000.00 PHP from PMPC to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

Maricel is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase fertilizer and pesticides. This loan will be her fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to support her family.

----------------------- About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers pesticides.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia U. is a 43-year-old married mother of two school-aged children, from the city of Dipolog. To make a living, Virginia owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Virginia joined Kiva partner, Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC), to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as working capital and to purchase additional inventory. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the sixth loan she has taken out with PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell in her general store

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda M. is from the village of Tinaclaan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Minda is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Minda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Minda has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Minda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Minda is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Minda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand her business.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Enhtuya

texts.en: Enhtuya B. lives with his wife and 3-year-old daughter in Arhanghay, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His daughter goes to a local kindergarten. He has a small business selling food. He owns a small food store on the busiest street in Arhanghay. He sells various food products, including wheat products, soft drinks, and candies. He mostly purchases his food products from the wholesale markets in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He started his business in 2008 with 700,000 MNT (1 USD = 1,400 MNT) and his business capital has now increased to 4,000,000 MNT. In the future, he hopes to expand his food store by adding more food items. Enhtuya requests a loan to purchase more food products for his business.

loans.use: To purchase food products for his business

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
"Twenty-five years, we have been farming. My husband and I grow rice to be able to feed and clothe our family. We wanted to grow our business more so that we could send our child to school and be able to provide her a brighter future," says Rosie S., a 46-year-old mother of one child. In addition to growing rice, she also raises pigs. Raising pigs is another way she thinks could supplement her family's income.

She would like to ask for a loan of 10,000 PHP from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and chemicals. The loan will really help to improve their harvest and sustain their pig business.

CEVI is providing financial services to the poor. CEVI provides not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long S. is 27-year-old, a modest-village woman and mother of two children who attend school.

She and her husband raise ducks. Long also sells eggs. She sells her poultry to buyers when they are not producing eggs.

Recently, Long sold her mature duck for slaughtering. She lacks the money needed to continue investing in her business, so she is applying for a $500 loan to purchase more feed and small ducks to breed.

loans.use: Purchase feed and small ducks.

loans.name: Wilfred

texts.en:
Wilfredy M. is a farmer in Tanzanian. He keeps beef and dairy cattle and goats. He sells forty litters of milk daily to customers for domestic uses. He also gets income from selling goats to meet customer needs.

His plans are to increase the number of livestock. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to boost his business.

loans.use: Expand his livestock.

loans.name: Adebisi

texts.en: Adebisi is 34 years old and married with two children.  She sells jewelry.   Adebisi is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more jewelry to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Ork

texts.en:
Ork N., at 50 years old, is an older villager that lives in the Province of Pursat, Cambodia. She is a widow, her husband died of senility years ago. Right now, she has four children: three are married and have already started new family homes, whilst the other one is single and works as a staff member for a casino hotel in Phnom Penh City.

Ork N. currently works growing a kind of local crop. In addition, she raises pigs in a cage behind her house. Ork N. requested a loan in order to buy a sow to breed for babies to sell. She proposes to use the rest of loan to pay for plowing a field.

loans.use: For a breeding sow and to have a field plowed

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia is 47 years old and married with five children. She sells tailoring materials like zippers, landings, etc.  She is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more tailoring materials to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo is 39 years old and married with 2 children. She sells medicines   She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en: Zainab is 42 years old and married with 5 children. She sells drinks and provisions.  She is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase a generator as an alternative source of power. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchases a generator

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo is 41 years old and married with 4 children. Taiwo is a tailor and he makes good suits for his customers. He is requesting for the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more tailoring materials to make more suits to sell. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en: Kemi O. is 50 years old and married with 3 children. Kemi sells foodstuffs. She is requesting the loan amount of 60,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Cette jeune femme est célibataire, devant subvenir à ses propres charges, elle a appris le métier de la cuisine et  a ouvert son propre restaurant, elle sert à ses clients de la spécialité togolaise comme la pâte, du fufu. Ses plats sont très appréciés. Les produits de première nécessité pour l’activité de la restauration étant épuisés, elle  sollicite son premier crédit qui lui permettra de s’approvisionner avec 4 sacs de riz, 1 sacs de charbons, 7 boîtes de tomates, 1 bidon de 25l et divers.
texts.en:
This is a young woman who is unmarried. Having to support herself, she learned to cook as a trade and opened her own restaurant. She serves her customers Togolese specialties, such as pâte and fufu. Her dishes are greatly appreciated. Since the necessary ingredients for her restaurant business are out of stock, she's requesting her first loan that will enable her to resupply herself with four sacks of rice, a sack of charcoal, seven cans of tomatoes, a 24-liter drum of cooking oil, and various other items.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sack of rice, charcoal, canned tomatoes, a drum of oil, etc.

loans.name: Bolatitu

texts.en: Bolatitu is 40 years old and married with 3 children. Bolatitu sells sarongs and bags. She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more sarongs and bags to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and bags to sell

loans.name: Muon

texts.en:
Pictured is Mrs. Muon M., 44, who lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia. She and her husband make a living by planting a variety of domestic crops; they grow things like rice, vegetables, fruits, and some flowers. They run their business on their own land that was inherited from their grandparents. They can grow twice a year, and will sell their crops every two months to buyers after they begin growing them.

Besides the farm work, Muon M.’s husband also leaves from their house to work in construction. Because the agricultural business is the family’s main way to earn a living, Muon M. is applying for a $1000 loan as capital to support her farming job by buying a cow, fertilizers, irrigating water, plowing a field, etc.

loans.use: To buy a cow and farming supplies

loans.name: Mkorofi Si Mwenzetu Group

texts.en:
Halima is single. For many years, Haliama has been a juice and bites (chapati) seller in the Jang’ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Mkorofi si mwenzetu group loan (group code: 2071). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $125. Every day she works at her business for 10 hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can add to her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Riziki and Angela. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more flour, sugar, fruits, and other items to expand her business

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr: Cette femme a commencé en 2005 la fabrication et vente de pain,  avec cette activité elle subvient convenablement à ses besoins, les stocks de matière utiles à la fabrication de pain étant épuisé, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner et sollicite par conséquent de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 06 sacs de farine de blé, 06 sacs de sucre, 20 boîtes de levure et du bois de chauffe.
texts.en:
This is a woman who stared making and selling bread in 2005. With this work, she supports herself appropriately. Since her stock of supplies used in making bread is exhausted, she would like to stock up again and is thus requesting her first loan from WAGES to buy six sacks of flour, six sacks of sugar, twenty containers of leavening, and some firewood.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wheat flour, sugar, leavening, and firewood

loans.name: Abiba

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de l’eau en sachet « pure WATER » et du jus, elle fait cette activité depuis 2003. Il existe une école à proximité de son lieu de commerce, à la sortie des classes, les jeunes viennent acheter chez elle, cela lui permet de réaliser de bonnes recettes. Son stock a diminué et elle souhaitera se réapprovisionner. Ayant déjà obtenu un premier crédit, elle sollicite de WAGES son second crédit pour acheter 10 sachets de sucre, 4 carton de plastique pour emballer le jus, et 400 sachets de « pure WATER ».
Elle est veuve et a à sa seule charge ses 04 enfants.
texts.en:
This is a women who earns an income selling "Pure WATER" in bags and juices. She has been in this business since 2003. There is a school near her place of business. When classes let out, the youngsters come and buy from her. This enables her to realize a good income. Her inventory has shrunk, and she would like to stock up again. Having already obtained a loan, she's requesting her second loan from WAGES to buy ten packets of sugar, four boxes of plastic for packaging juices, and 400 bags of "Pure WATER". She is a widow and is alone in supporting her four children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, plastic, and baggies of "Pure Water"

loans.name: Ayo

texts.en: Ayo is 38 years old and married with 3 children. He sells electronics, like television sets. He is requesting a loan for the amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more electronics to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

loans.name: Kesi

texts.en:
Kesi has been a bites seller in the Jang’ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar for 3 years. She belongs to Yarabi tupe Salama group loan (group code: 2030). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $25. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can add to her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Kesi is 35 years old, married, and has given birth to one child who is now 4 years old.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Heri

texts.en:
Heri P. is a jovial and enterprising 28-year-old man. He is married with 2 children. He lives in the Kuta area of Bali with his extended family, about 8 of whom work for him making wristbands out of leather scraps. He sells these to local and international wholesalers. Heri’s wristbands are sold in Bali at big supermarkets like Matahari and Centro.

Heri wants to borrow 1m IDR (about USD 100) to buy raw materials. This is his 3rd loan with Kiva. He has always made repayments on time or even ahead of schedule. Heri’s clients pay him only when he delivers his finished goods. For that reason, loans are very important to him because they allow him to buy leather scraps to make wristbands for which he has already received orders.

Eventually, Heri would like to build his credit history to the point where he can borrow 20m IDR (about USD 2000), which is enough to buy 1 ton (1000 kg) of leather scraps. When he can afford to raise that amount of capital, he will also bring in more family members from Java to help him produce more wristbands faster. He is confident that he has the client base to support a higher rate of production, especially during the busy tourist season.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Résidente du quartier d’agoè démakpoè qui est un quartier périphérique au centre de la ville de Lomé, cette femme est une veuve  qui a à sa seule charge ses 04 enfants. Afin de subvenir correctement à leur charge, elle a entamé en 2003 le commerce des produits d’alimentation générale. Cette activité est très rentable pour elle. Présentement elle veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 01panier de tomates fraîches, 04cartons de poissons, 05 bidons d’huile et divers.
texts.en:
A resident of Agoè Démakpoè, a beltway district in the middle of the city of Lomé, this woman is a widow who is supporting her four children all by herself. To provide for them appropriately, she started a grocery business in 2003. This business is very profitable for her. Presently, she wants to stock up again and is requesting her first loan from WAGES to buy a basket of fresh tomatoes, four boxes of fish, five drums of cooking oil, and various other items.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, fish, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: 10-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Mai Lê Thị (63) is a 64-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hóa. Mai is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 10 Nam Ngạn (17-05-10).

Mai is widowed and has 2 adult children. To making a living, Mai owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, running a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Mai has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1.200.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, Mai joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mai has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2.442.600VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Mai plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. N. Thị Yến (64) is a 36-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector, running a food stall.

2. T. Thị Thanh (66) is a 31-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector, operating a tailoring business.

3. N. Thị Cúc (67) is a 64-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector, operating a service-based business. 4. Ngô Thị Gấm (68) is a 60-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector, running a food stall.

5. N. Thị Hương (51) is a 46-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector, raising livestock.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

*Note: Many FPW borrowers have expressed a desire to borrow larger amounts to make more significant investments in their businesses. In response to this, FPW has recently added a new loan product of 6.000.000 VND to its Thanh Hoa City branch portfolio.

Mai Lê Thị (63) là 64 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hóa. Mai là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 10 Nam Ngạn (17.05.10). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương. Mai thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Mai kiếm được khoảng 40.000 VND. Vào 2007, Mai đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Mai đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 2.442.600 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. N. Thị Yến (64) là 36 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 2. T. Thị Thanh (66) là 31 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc. 3. N. Thị Cúc (67) là 64 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. 4. Ngô Thị Gấm (68) là 60 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 5. N. Thị Hương (51) là 46 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. .

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: James

texts.en: James O. is 41 years old and married with 5 children. He sells palm oil retail to his customers. He is requesting the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more palm oil to sell. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil to sell

loans.name: Yarabi Tupe Salama Group

texts.en:
Ziada is a retail businesswoman; she has been selling different items in the Jang’ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar for 3 years. She belongs to Yarabi Tupe Salama group loan and she currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately US$ 40. Every day she works at her business from 7:00 am to 8:00 pm.

She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to add to her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Ziada is 27 years old and she is single. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Moza, who has her own small business selling firewood, charcoal, and other items in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more items to add to her current stock

loans.name: Alidou

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pièces détachées de voitures,  son stock de marchandises a diminué, il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter  10 disques d’occasion, 10 patins de 18 troues, 15 patins de 12 troues, 10 grands rivés, 10 petits rivés et divers.
Il exerce ce commerce depuis 2006 et s’approvisionne au marché du port autonome de Lomé.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who earns an income from commerce in automobile spare parts. His stock of merchandise has shrunk. He's requesting his first loan from WAGES to buy ten used discs, ten 18-hole flanges, fifteen 12-hole flanges, ten large rivets, ten small rivets, and various other items. He has been in this business since 2006 and stocks up at the marketplace of the Autonomous Port of Lomé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used discs, flanges, rivets, etc

loans.name: Nazakat

texts.en:
K. Nazakat is a happy mother of 3 children. She is 49 years old and married. For 18 years she has been selling foodstuffs in the local food market. Nazakat’s wish is to expand her business, offering various types of foodstuffs to her customers who pass through this market. She works with one aim in mind, to provide the best possible example and way of life for her beloved children who are the apple of her eye and the reason for her daily efforts.

With this opportunity and with the immense love she feels as a mother and her desire to succeed, she is appealing to your generosity and is requesting a loan of 3000 USD in order to increase the range of her goods. You can be an important link in the growth of this business by supporting Nazakat.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs  to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Tuimarike Group

texts.en:
For many years, Ridhwana has been a juice and bites (chapati) seller in the Jang’ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Tuimarike group loan (Group code 2075). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately US$ 100. Every day she works at her business for 10 hours.

She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more sugar, wheat flour, fruit, and cooking oil for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Ridhwana is 23 years old and she is single. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Shekha. who has her own small business selling eggs in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, wheat flour, fruit, and cooking oil

loans.name: Osita

texts.en:
Osita M. is from the town of Luyong Bonbon Opol Mis. Or.. She is 58 years old. Osita is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Osita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a sari-sari (variety) shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Osita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Osita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Osita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Osita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and to rennovate her residence.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Khosiyat

texts.en:
K. Khosiyat is 56 years old. She is a widow and the mother of three children. Khosiyat is doing all the best to ensure the best future for her children. That is the reason that she has been running her own business for 19 years already. She has a place in the central market for selling foodstuffs such as macaroni, oil, sugar, spices and other items. She works from 8:00 a.m. till 5:00 p.m.

The business is stable and allows her to improve the living conditions of her family. Now Khosiyat needs a loan for increasing the range of her goods. She requests 3000 USD for a term of 12 months. Khosiyat and her children are sincerely grateful for your support.

Also he doesn’t charge much for his services. Now he wants to borrow money so he can buy newer instruments for hair cutting. This way Akram thinks he can offer a better service for his clients and earn more and improve his living standard.

He bakes the national bread “lepeshka” at home and his wife helps him with his business. Having many customers, Farrukh sells the majority of his products just from his place. However, he is also running a trading place in the central local market. Now Farrukh requests 5,000 Somoni in order to purchase flour wholesale as required for his business. He is grateful for all those supporting him and promises to manage the loan with accuracy. loans.name: Ankabenkélenkan 2. 2 (Soyons Unies). Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Ankabenkélenkan 2. 2 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Fonfona de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et au moins 5 enfants et  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles soeurs  etc. 
Elles  cultivent principalement  du riz et de l’arachide.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  Ankabenkélenkan 2.2 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq ans. Après avoir correctement remboursés  les quatre premiers prêts, elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des semences de riz, d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au marché de Fonfona, M’pessoba et Zansoni. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au marché de M’pessoba et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail et en gros, au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Ankabenkélenkan 2.2 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 70 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Ankabenkélenkan 2.2 Group is a group of married women from the village of Fonfona in the main city of Koutiala (in Mali's third administrative region). They have an average age of 35 and at least five children each, and live in large, extended traditional families with their children, husbands, parents-in-law, sisters-in-law, etc. They grow mainly rice and groundnuts. Keen to make a profit from their agriculture business, the members of the Ankabenkélenkan 2.2 group decided five years ago to join Soro Yiriwaso’s loan program. Having fully repaid their first four loans, they are now on their fifth country loan. The current loan will be used to buy rice and groundnut seeds, small equipment and fertilizer at the markets in Fonfona, M’pessoba and Zansoni. After the harvest season, the crops are placed in storage for a certain period of time to increase in value before being sold at retail and wholesale at the market in M’pessoba or surrounding markets for cash to a clientele composed of retailers, in general from the large towns. Once the crops are sold, the members of the Ankabenkélenkan 2.2 group each expect to make a profit of CFA 70,000, which will be used to repay the loan and for everyday family expenses.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is 28 years old and married with three children. She has a boutique where she sells clothes and shoes.

She is requesting the loan of N60,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchases more clothes to sell

loans.name: 13 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en: Nga Võ Thị (82) is a 43-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hóa. She is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. The official name of this borrowing group is 13 Nam Ngạn (17.06.13). Nga is married and has three school-aged children. She owns and operates a food stall, selling a variety of food products in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 1,500,000 VND a month. In 2007, Nga joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Nga is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will also be used to invest in expanding her business. The loan will be her 4th loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. N. Thị Đạo (76) is a 54-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector. 2. Lê Thị Tâm (78) is a 38-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food. 3. N. Thị Tính (79) is a 40-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business operating a butcher shop. 4. C. Thị Thúy (80) is a 42-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall. 5. N. Thị Xuyên (81) is a 44-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương. Nga thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Nga kiếm được khoảng 1.500.000 VND. Vào 2007, Nga đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Nga đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. N. Thị Đạo (76) là 54 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. 2. Lê Thị Tâm (78) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 3. N. Thị Tính (79) là 40 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng T.t. 4. C. Thị Thúy (80) là 42 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 5. N. Thị Xuyên (81) là 44 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Kurban

texts.en:
K. Kurban is 57 years old. He is married with 4 children. Kurban sells confectionery and other foodstuffs in the market. He has been in this business for 5 years. This activity generates the main income for the family of Kurban. Since Kurban is very popular in the market selling fresh and tasty foodstuffs, he tries to maintain a wide range of goods. Thus, today Kurban requests 1000 US Dollars for purchasing foodstuffs to sell.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing more, varied goods to sell

loans.name: Phann

texts.en:
Mrs. Phann S., 57, has had a farming job since early 2000. She always grows vegetable crops to sell in the local market. Normally, she retails her mature crops two months after she plants them. She is married to Keit Bunthon, 67, who works with her in the farm work. This humble older couple has four children: two are single and the others are married. All four of their children are employed at different jobs and have provided their income to better meet their family’s food needs.

Phann S. is requesting a loan in order to help support her children’s businesses since they are lacking capital to make their businesses more successful.

loans.use: To help support her children’s businesses

loans.name: Davron

texts.en:
A. Davron is a married father with two children. Davron has been a farmer for the last 5 years. Farming is a passion for him. He practices both dairy farming and mixed-crop farming. He says he has chosen farming as a career because the produce from his farm has a ready market. His challenge at the moment is that he is not fully utilizing his land; this is because he used up all his proceeds from the last harvest to pay his children's school fees and was not able to buy the seeds and fertilizers needed to plant all his land.

Davron is requesting a loan of 800 USD to be able to purchase the resources needed to plough the whole farm for the next planting season. He will purchase assorted fertilizer stock and seeds.

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Houdada

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur est un jardinier, il fait aussi  la culture des fleurs, il est sollicité pour  arranger, tailler ou implanter des jardins publiques et  privés. En ce moment il a besoin de certains produits nécessaires à son activité de jardinage. N’ayant jamais obtenu de WAGES, il sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter 06 sacs de NPK, 04n sacs d’urée, 04 boîtes de carotte, 02 litres de deltacal, 04 kg de mémacur, 01 litre d’agri-stomp, 01 pulvérisateur.
Il est marié et a 01 enfant, c’est avec le revenu de son activité de jardinage qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman is a gardener. He also grows flowers. People seek him out to arrange, shape, or plant public and private gardens. At the moment, he has need of certain products necessary for his gardening business. Never having had a WAGES loan, he's requesting his first loan to buy six sacks of NPK, four sacks of urea, four containers of carrots, two liters of deltacal, four kilos of mémacur, a liter of agri-stomp, and a sprayer. He is married and has a child. The revenues from his gardening business is what supports his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy NPK, urea, deltaca, mémacur, and other gardening products

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy N. is 31 years old and married with 5 children. She sells building materials to make a living. She is requesting the loan amount of N 30,000 to purchase more building materials to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Mukim

texts.en:
Mukim is a farmer. He lives with his family, including his wife, 6 children that are school-aged, and his parents also. His wife helps him with caring for their land. In the past they have had problems in harvesting; having to sell their crop in advance and see reduced earnings.

By this time Mukim has gained a lot of experience in his business and now his crop is one of the most sought after at the market. He now faces a small problem because his field is infertile, which makes it difficult to grow his crops. To solve this problem, he has decided to request a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers to support the field and make his crops more productive.

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Welburga

texts.en:
Welburga O. is from the town of Luyongbonbon Opol Misamis oriental. She is 49 years old. Welburga is separated from her spouse and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Welburga owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, operating a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing slightly used "ukay-ukay" clothing to local community members. Welburga has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Welburga joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Welburga is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Welburga from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and save for future emergencies.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Mavzuna

texts.en:
For more than 8 years, Mavzuna, together with her mother (pictured), has been working in the largest local market of the city. She sells rice and cottonseed oil. Her business is situated in the central market where there are always a lot of people, so that the business is very stable and generates stable income for her family.

Mavzuna has been working with IMON for a year and has proved herself an accurate client. Today she requests 3500 Somoni for purchasing rice and cottonseed oil to sell. Mavzuna thanks all for support and promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing rice and cottonseed oil for re-sale

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is 31 years old and she is married, She has been a food items seller in the Jang’ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar for 5 years. She belongs to Tukubalianae group loan (Group code 2009). She currently earns very little monthly profit. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her fourth loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items  for resale

loans.name: Maimuna

texts.en:
Maimuna has been an animal keeper and has owned a small shop in the Jang’ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar for 5 years. She belongs to Salmina group loan (Group code 2019). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately US$ 90. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and soap to add to her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Maimuna is 26 years old, married, and has 3 children: ages 8, 6 and 3.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and soap to add to her current stock

loans.name: Ankabenkélenkan 2 .3 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Ankabenkélenkan 2.3 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Fonfona de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles cultivent principalement  du riz et de l’arachide en secondaire.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  Ankabenkélenkan 2.3 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq ans. Après avoir correctement remboursés  les quatre premiers   prêts, elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de riz d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au marché de Fonfona, M’pessoba et Zansoni. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au marché de M’pessoba et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail et en gros, au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Ankabenkélenkan 2.3 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 70 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Ankabenkélenkan 2.3 Group is a group of married women from the village of Fonfona in the main city of Koutiala (in Mali's third administrative region). They live in large, extended traditional families with their children, husbands, parents-in-law, sisters-in-law, etc. They have an average age of 45 and at least six children each. Their main crop is rice, with groundnuts their secondary crop. Keen to make a profit from their agriculture business, the members of the Ankabenkélenkan 2.3 Group decided five years ago to join Soro Yiriwaso’s loan program. Having fully repaid their first four loans, they are now on their fifth country loan. The current loan will be used to buy a decent quantity of rice and groundnut seeds, and small equipment and fertilizer for farming at the markets in Fonfona, M’pessoba and Zansoni. After the harvest season, the crops are placed in storage for a certain period of time to increase in value before being sold at retail and wholesale at the market in M’pessoba or surrounding markets for cash to a clientele composed of retailers, in general from the large towns. Once the crops are sold, the members of the Ankabenkélenkan 2.3 Group each expect to make a profit of CFA 70,000, which will be used to repay the loan and for everyday family expenses.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and small farm equipment

loans.name: Muborak

texts.en:
Y. Muborak is 48 years old. She is married and has four children. Muborak is running a little catering business where she provides traditional dishes. She’s renting a catering room which is located in a school which allows Muborak to have many customers, the majority of whom are school-children.

Every day she purchases the freshest foodstuffs and cooks delicious dishes. Now Muborak is asking for a loan of 3600 Somoni in order to expand her business and in that way to earn enough to be able to send one of her children to the University next year. She will use the loan for buying flour, oil and other foodstuffs. Muborak thanks all supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: Purchasing flour, oil, and other foodstuffs

loans.name: Sairiniso

texts.en:
Since 1992, Sairiniso, a loving grandmother of three grandchildren, has dedicated herself to processing granulated sugar and then making from it a variety of pastries to sell in local markets. She begins her workday at early morning along with her daughter-in-law, who is also engaged in this business. Sairiniso’s dreams is to grow her business so she can offer her products personally in markets throughout the regions of her country, thereby earning greater income. For this reason, she is requesting a loan of 5000 Somoni to expand her business by purchasing additional equipment for processing granulated sugar. Let’s get behind this dedicated mother to help her keep making progress in her business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. loans.use: To purchase new equipment for processing granulated sugar.

loans.name: Apolonia

texts.en: Apolonia O. is 45 years old and married with nine children. She sells secondhand clothes. She is requesting the loan of N30,000 to purchase more secondhand clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchases more secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Paz

texts.en: Paz O. is from the town of Luyongbonbon Opol, Misamis Oriental. She is 57 years old, widowed, and has four adult children. Paz owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Paz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family and to purchase improvements for the house. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Aslonjon

texts.en:
K. Aslonjon is a lively entrepreneur with a small business selling shoes for teenagers. He is an experienced entrepreneur having been self-employed for the past 15 years. Business has been good for Aslonjon. There is always demand for shoes and as the economy has improved in Tajikistan, more people have been able to afford new shoes.

Aslonjon is married and has 4 children. He is doing all his best to ensure his children have the best future. Aslonjon has requested a loan of $800 USD to increase his available working capital. Eventually Aslonjon hopes to have his own small store. This loan will help him purchase new inventory and continue to invest in his business.
